text:
So really glad to be here. I was telling Michael I assigned
this seminar as an extra credit

point in my interaction
design class, so students can watch any of
the seminars from the past

or in the present, and write
a little summary of it. And that's been such
a great assignment.

So it's really great to
actually get to be here myself. So as you may know,
this is actually

a really difficult
time for trans people in the US in particular. And so I wanted to
begin by highlighting

this anti-trans
political climate that we are in right now. And I think when I was giving
talks about a year ago,

I'm not sure how many people
really knew about this stuff, but I feel like it's
really front and center

right now in a way that I
definitely wasn't anticipating. So pretty much as soon
as the new administration

came into office, there
was an executive order that was basically
defining gender

as only being two binary sexes. And these are some of the
implications of that order.

So recognizing people as only
men or women, when it's actually quite more complex than that.

Denying requests for
passport gender markers. Moving trans women
into men's prisons.

Bans on trans service
members in the military. Restrictions on gender affirming
care for youth, and also

in some states for adults. And then barring schools
from supporting students who are socially transitioning.

And there is always something
new going on at the state level. The more recent two things
that have happened are in Iowa.

They have passed basically
restrictions on trans people's rights, making it so that
trans people have fewer rights

than other people in the state. This is things like bathroom
bans, which you may think,

it's only a bathroom, that's
not that big of a deal. But if you can't use
a public restroom, you can't be in public spaces
for more than a few hours.

So these have really
big implications. And then in Texas, this
is a new proposed bill.

It hasn't been passed
yet, but basically it makes it illegal to
identify as transgender.

And I mentioned some of
these consequences before. But of course, there's
restrictions on travel if you

cannot have your
passport updated. And then really dire
consequences for trans women

who are being transferred
over to men's jails. And so even though these
are only executive orders,

that doesn't mean
that they are the law. There's a lot of people
complying with these orders

as though they were law. So there are very real
consequences here.

And I'm sure many of you
have seen this list of words that we are feeling
that we're restricted

from using these words in grant
proposals for academic research. And I am showing these
words because I want

us to keep saying these words. These are censored
in some ways, but I think we need to still say
these words, use these words,

talk about these things even
if people are telling us we should not. And that's partly why I made
this website the other day,

that just cycles through
these words in a random order. It was something I did want
to be able to see myself,

so I just put it
together very quickly. So all of this is context for
the environment in which I've

been doing this research. And this is an example of how
trans people have been fighting

back against this hostile
political environment, by creating technology or what
I like to call trans technology.

So this is an example called
the Trans Formations Project. And this is a website that
displays this database of all

of the different bills that
have been proposed or passed or not passed in different
states and in the US

more broadly. So it's really hard to keep
track of all of these bills. There's just so many
of them, and people

don't know necessarily which
ones are moving forward and which ones are not. So this is a way
that you can look up,

for your particular state,
what's happening there or for the country more broadly.

And that's just
one example of what I've spent the last several
years studying and trying

to document in this book. I'm really excited
for you to read it. It's available free, open
access on MIT Press's website.

There's also physical copies
available at bookstores and online.

And I want to give a few
more examples of some of the technologies that
have been responding

to this political moment. Now, I did this research
a few years ago. But when I was doing
the interviews,

this was right when some
of these state-level bills were being proposed
and passed in states

like Texas and Idaho, Florida. And this is an app called
Trans Family Network.

And I think this is such
a great example of ways that technology can help
in moments like this.

Because basically, the way this
started was, a bunch of people were organizing
on Twitter, which

was a very different
platform at the time, and trying to connect people
who needed support with people

who could provide support. So, for instance, there
were some families in states like Texas, where
they had a trans child who

was no longer able to
access health care, they wanted to be able to
go to a different state, but they may have financial
costs that they couldn't afford.

They may need help
with transportation, all kinds of different
resources like that. And initially, people were
using a spreadsheet, a Google

spreadsheet, to coordinate,
matching people up. But the problem there
is that really anyone

could access this spreadsheet. And so people were not
sure if the people who were offering support
were actually safe,

if they could
trust those people. It just wasn't a really
good technological mechanism for that.

And so a group of trans
women, mostly highly

paid, working in
Silicon Valley, they also met on Twitter
around political moment,

and got together and
started creating this app. And many of them took
about two weeks off of work

to create this and
basically formalize what was happening
in the spreadsheet. But with this app,
they were able to have

a more formalized
vetting process, ways of keeping people safe, ways of
matching people up with people

that could provide support. So I think this is a
really exciting example of what trans technology can do
as a form of resistance here.

And this is another
thing we've seen a lot of, is visualizations
of the US showing

which states are more
safe, which states have more bills being proposed
that are anti-LGBTQ,

things like that. So the map on the
left, this is just showing the total bills,
not necessarily which ones have passed.

But the one on the right, which
is created by Aaron Reed, who's a very prominent trans
activist and generalist,

she's actually been doing
this risk assessment. So she's analyzing
all of this data and showing us which
states are safe,

which ones you really should
not travel to if you're trans. So you can see that there are
two states that she recommends

do not travel. That's Texas and Florida. And then there's a little youth
map on the lower corner there

that shows how safe things
are for trans youth. And people have been
using this actually

to move to different
states, move from some of these red
states to blue states. There was a survey that
showed that about 5%

of trans people living in some
of these very dangerous states have moved, and way more
than that are considering it.

Another form of support comes
in the form of mutual aid. So this is something
called a stream

team called Gender Federation. And stream team is something
I had no idea what that was

until I started this research. But basically, it's
a group of people who come together and do
live streams to raise funds

for people who need
support for something. And in this case, this
Gender Federation stream team

was interested in raising money
for people who needed gender affirming medical care, but
also for things like emergency,

housing costs, things like that. And so this is another way of
providing technological support

in this moment. And I tend to find some comfort
and power from Chase Strangio.

He's the first
openly trans lawyer who has presented arguments
at the US Supreme Court.

And this is a quote
from his Instagram that reminds me a lot
of trans technologies. He says, "We have a profound
and powerful ability to care

for each other, to share
resources and care, create art, and find the blueprints from
those that charted these paths

long before we got there." So things like sharing
resources, creating art,

coordinating with other
people to support each other. I think that's a lot
of what I'm seeing

in the world of
trans technologies. So there's a concept
called trans care,

and this comes from Malatino. And he defines this
as trans people showing up for each other,
supporting each other,

helping to address each other's
needs, in the absence of support from mainstream systems. So one example here would be, if
one person gets a trans surgery

and then a friend
takes care of them while they're recovering,
because often there are not formal resources
for things like this.

And from trans care, I
developed this concept of technological trans care,
which is trans people creating

innovative technological
mechanisms to support each other and address the needs that
they and their communities

face when mainstream systems and
technologies reject or exclude them. So an example here
is TransCare+.

This is a resource
website that provides important resources for people. And this trans
technology, I would argue,

is a form of trans care. But it's different
because it's one to many rather than being one to one.

So for something
like TransCare+, the creator of this website
would not necessarily know who

all the people are
that they're helping, who are accessing this site. So there are many people who are
receiving help from that, rather

than it being
one-to-one interaction. And so technological
trans care can

be an important way
for trans people to fight back against this
discriminatory and hostile

systems and political
environments. So before I go
further, I just wanted

to acknowledge my
collaborators who've worked with me on this work. So this includes students
and postdocs and also

some of my co-PIs on the grant
that's funding some of this. And a book, it comes out
with one person's name on it,

but it's never actually
just a solo process. So although I wrote it
myself, a lot of people

collaborated with me on
some of the work here. And for methods,
it was interviews.

So over 100 interviews
with different creators of trans technologies For
recruitment, we basically

started by creating a list
of what we were considering trans technologies,
and then we did

some searching for other ones
we may not have heard of. And we started there by
contacting people and inviting

them for an interview. At the end of each
interview, we also asked people for other
examples of people

that they considered were
making trans technology or other technologies
that they could think of.

So it was a snowball
sampling approach there. At the same time,
I was also doing

a lot of digital
ethnography, so that meant I was using a lot of
these technologies myself.

I was following them
on social media, signing up for
their email lists, and then really engaging
with that content.

And then I also attended a
conference called the trans Tech Summit for two years in a row.

And then for data analysis. It was primarily this
reflexive thematic analysis.

And one note there, most of
the participants in this study actually wanted to be identified
rather than anonymous.

So you will see in this
presentation and in the book, I actually use people's
real names many times,

and that's because that's
what they preferred. So there are some cases
where I anonymize people when that was their preference.

So I've been talking a lot
about trans technology, but I haven't yet told
you what exactly that is.

And I have two definitions
here, and these come from the interviews. So basically, I
asked people how they

were conceptualizing
trans technology and what they thought it was. And from there, I came up with
this first definition, which

is a more practical definition. And that's technology that
addresses the unique needs and challenges faced by
trans people and communities.

And it's often
designed in response to the lack of trans inclusion
in more mainstream technologies.

So an example here would
be if someone wants a way to track their hormone
dosages, and then they

create an app to do that. But there's also a more
theoretical definition.

And this is drawing from trans
studies and queer theory. And this is technology
that embraces change

and/or transition, fosters the
creation of new trans worlds and opens up new possibilities
for what technology means

and what it can do. And I will give you some
examples later in the talk of what I mean here.

So here's just a few examples
of some of the technologies in the data set. And some of these are more
standard apps and websites.

But there are also
things like AR and VR, prosthetics, different
types of supplies,

even things like podcasts,
things like that. So it definitely was not
just digital technologies.

It was a much wider range
of types of technology. And along with
technological trans care,

there was another key theme that
was going throughout the study and across the book. And this is ambivalence.

And trans technologies
are really wrapped up in ambivalence. So this means that several
seemingly incompatible things

can actually be true
at the same time. So trans sec creators
navigated tensions

between competing emotions,
goals, and desires that they experience
simultaneously.

So this included things
like individualists and community-based
design methods. And I'm using "and" here instead
of versus to demonstrate this

ambivalence. Privileged and inclusive
technology design,

capitalist and anti-capitalist
approaches, and then utopian and dystopian
trans futures.

So I want to give you
an example of what I mean here by ambivalence.

So I was on Twitter
in early 2022, and I came across this
tweet by Sasha Winter, who

was one of the people I
interviewed for this study, and she was announcing something
called the Trans Rage Jam.

And basically, this was a
moment where a lot of people were very angry about
this legislation and all

of this anti-trans sentiment
that was coming through at that time. And they wanted to do
something about it.

And a game jam is
another thing, I didn't know what that was
until I started this study, but it's basically a bunch
of people coming together,

creating their own games
on a certain theme. So for this one, the
theme is trans rage.

And you can see it
has a color scheme, it has certain fonts
that go with it. And then the people
actually work together

within an online community
that Sasha was also running as part of a Discord server.

So basically, they could do
some of this collaboratively. And this is what
they came up with.

There were 82 submissions. You can see that they all are
on this similar color scheme.

They're all using
these types of fonts and these themes
of anger and rage.

But then a few months later,
I was back on Twitter. I saw that Sasha had
posted another tweet,

and this one was announcing
the Trans Joy Jam. And this was just
a few months later.

It was summer of the
same year, and you can see the color scheme
is completely different. It's involving a rainbow and
sparkles and things like this.

And here are the
submissions that came in for the Trans Joy Jam. You can see they are all much
more bright and colorful.

Their themes are happy,
things including joy. And what I want to
really emphasize here

is that these are both
existing at the same time, within the same people. So it's not that this
group of trans people

was just so angry and
enraged in March and April, and then a few months
later, over the summer,

they were just suddenly
filled with joy. It's that both of these
things exist at the same time

within these people. So from there, I want to go
into the primary arguments

in the book. And the first is that
creating trans technology can be powerful and empowering
because tech creators have

this agency to create
the tools that they themselves and their
communities as well need

to navigate the world. But when trans
communities are not

involved in design
processes, then this can lead to this overly
individualistic design that then

speaks to more privileged
trans people's needs. And so I argue that trans
tech creation can actually

have the most impact
and best address trans needs if diverse trans
communities are meaningfully

involved in design processes. So in this first part, I'm
arguing that creating trans tech

can be really powerful
and empowering. Because of this
agency, people have to create these
tools for themselves

and their communities. And so a lot of times,
people are really drawing from their
own experiences

very directly when
creating technology. And this can be really powerful
because creators are using

their skills that they have. They're using their agency to
build something that society is not providing to them.

And so this can be a form
of technological trans care where people are
increasing agency,

not just for themselves, but
for community members as well. And the first example
I want to give of this

is Aaron Reid's informed consent
hormone replacement therapy map.

So informed consent is a method
of medical care, where basically

you don't need to get a
letter from a psychiatrist or from a doctor. You can just say, I
want this medical care,

and these providers will
allow you to have it. And so Aaron was really drawing
from her own experience here.

She said, I was
30 and was trying to find a hormone
therapy clinic, and didn't know if
I could find one.

My struggles definitely made
me realize, is there really not a place where I can just go
online and look for the nearest

informed consent location to me? No, there wasn't. It didn't exist at all. And so just in dealing
with those frustrations,

I wanted to make this one day. I wanted to make sure
that people don't have to go through this one day.

So here she's really
exercising her own agency to create this
online resource that

can help lots of
other trans people all across the US
and even beyond,

and help them move forward
in their medical transition journeys. And so by drawing from
her own experiences

and basically creating what
she wanted to see in the world, she was extending this
technological trans care

to the people that
were accessing the map. And next, I want to
tell you about Anna.

So Anna, it's a pseudonym
for a participant who wanted to remain anonymous.

And she was a young
trans girl living in a rural area of the US. And when she was
eight years old,

she actually created her
own personal website. But beyond that, she was
also identifying problems

that other trans
people were facing. And she wasn't satisfied just
waiting around for solutions.

So she said, "I came
out when I was eight, and very few trans resources
whatsoever were around.

So there was this huge need. I didn't feel supported, so I
would need an online resource. There were also thousands
of other young trans people

who would need that
online resource too. So I worked with some friends
that I knew from the internet,

and we started this educational
resource for trans young people. I'm one of the two co-founders.

We were both 16-year-old
trans girls at the time. We didn't know how big it was
going to grow or how long it was

going to last, and it's
still running strong." And so her experience
here, creating

this educational resource
when she was a teenager, it just shows this agency
that a lot of trans people

do have to create the tools that
they want to see in the world. And so Anna is someone that
had the skills and resources.

She knew how to code
as a very young person, but she also did have
some limitations. So she lived in a very
rural area of the US

and didn't have very high
speed internet access. But still she was able
to make this work.

The next example I want to
give is actually local to here. It's a group called We are the
Ones We've Been Waiting For,

and they're a trans collective
in Oakland, California. They're focused on
art, music, community.

But their big thing is really
mutual aid and social justice. And so they created
this self-defense kit.

Basically, they call this part
of the program, Arm the Girl. So you can see what was involved
in the self-defense kit there.

And they created and
distributed hundreds of these self-defense kits. And this is a way to
really directly address

community needs. So one of the biggest
community needs is safety. And this is especially true for
transfeminine people of color.

So this is a way
that they were really just saying, here's a problem
that exists in our community, and here's a way that we are
going to help address it.

And so the second
part of my argument here is that when trans
communities are not

involved in design
processes, this can lead to overly
individualistic design that can speak primarily to more
privileged trans people's needs.

So in many cases, people
were creating technologies that were for people that
had identities very similar

to the creator themselves. And the majority of
trans tech creators do tend to be people
who are white.

They tend to be pretty
highly educated. They tend to be of higher
socioeconomic status

than the overall
trans community. And so that means that the needs
and desires of the people who

are creating technology
are not always very well aligned with the trans
population more broadly.

So there's this potential
for trans technologies to actually exclude the
most marginalized people

in the trans community. And that includes
people of color, trans people with lower
socioeconomic status,

things like that. So the first example
I want to give here

is, this is a site
called Shinigami Eyes, and it's a browser
extension that highlights transphobic and
trans-friendly pages on a web

browser using different colors. So you can see that everyday
feminism is included in there.

That means it's a safe
tool for-- or sorry, a safe site or page
for trans people. And then something like
the Family Research Council

is in red, and that's something
that's considered anti-trans. And there's also a crowdsourced
mechanism here where you can,

if you have this
browser extension, you can actually mark things
as safe or not safe yourself.

And so according
to their website, the creator, who is a
trans person themselves, was really creating
this tool in response

to their own experience of
being a trans person online and not knowing which
sites they could trust.

And I wasn't able to
speak with this creator. I did reach out to them, but
didn't receive a response.

So basically, all I
know about this tool is what I'm able to read online. And in the FAQs,
it says, how does

it know how to color each page? And the answer is,
the initial version is being created through a mix
of manual labeling and machine

learning, but you can
contribute your own labels. And so I started to
notice a lot of people

on Twitter talking
about this tool. And this person says that they
had installed Shinigami Eyes

and noticed a couple of things. So first, I immediately
noticed how many Black trans folks and
Black trans allies

are not marked safe, but how
many blatantly racist folks are. And then they
continued and said,

"If you're not safe
for Black trans people, you're not safe
for trans people." So in the little that I know
about how this tool was created,

and I actually don't know the
identity of the person who created it, but they did
this manual labeling process,

and it sounds like it
was just them maybe doing this on their own. So if they did have
biases, then that

could have crept into the
design of the initial machine learning algorithm. And so the result
then is that it's

more likely to mark white trans
people as safe, more likely to mark trans people of color or
Black trans people as not safe.

And so then, there's also
this crowdsourcing process, but we don't know who all is
involved in that crowdsourcing

process. And so it might have been
that that then perpetuated some of these biases as well.

So a better approach
would be to start out with the initial
labeling of the data set

with a diverse group
of trans people, so that you could build the
machine learning model based
on a less biased data set.

And this next example is the
creator of a very formative trans resource site.

And she was a white trans
woman, and she was actually very forthright with me
about her motivations

in building the site, primarily
for other people that were just very similar to herself. She said, "I wanted
to help the people who

are like me, who are
college educated, competitive in
white collar fields. So that was my grand scheme.

I was trying to make
it for everybody, but I was really focused on
people who I was most readily,

most easily able to help." So in this quote, if you
read between the lines, it sounds like that there
is some judgment here

towards trans people
who are not like her, so people who are not
college-educated and white. And it feels like there's
this harmful assumption here

about more marginalized
people, and that's likely inherent in the website itself. And so because she
is creating this site

and maintaining this site from
this more privileged frame of reference, then it
does have the potential

to exclude or to not
include resources that are most helpful for trans
people who are not like her,

so people who are not white,
well-educated and affluent.

And then the next example
is a site called the Digital Transgender Archive.

And this is an online
archive of trans content, but it does tend to skew
more towards content

of mostly white trans people. But the creator of this tool was
actually a lot more self-aware,

and was thinking a lot about how
his privilege and the privilege of the team who created the
site might shape the tools they

might bake in things
like bias and exclusion. So he said, "We're recognizing
the ways that the Digital

Transgender Archive is
slanted towards otherwise privileged factions
of trans communities, in ways that you can
probably readily anticipate.

I'm sure that the DTA
doesn't always feel like everyone's resource." So it was actually
really refreshing

when I was speaking to creators
who explicitly acknowledged some of the limitations and described
ways that they were thinking

about trying to address
some of these limitations because most of the
creators I spoke with were just leaving this
unstated and unaddressed.

But there are ways to
move beyond these more individualistic
design processes.

And so in the third
part of my argument, I argue that trans technology
creation can have most impact

and best address trans needs
if diverse community members are meaningfully involved
in design processes.

So this first example is
something called the Creative Futures Project. And this is a project in
which the creator worked

with three trans youth
to create virtual reality art for immersive storytelling.

And it eventually became
two different films. So the creator, Dylan Pare
said, "The linear film

would tell the story of
how these youth came up with their ideas, of what
stories they wanted to tell and what they were hoping people
would learn from their projects.

And then the 360 film was
where you can actually go into the art with them. They tell you about their art
that they've created and what

that means to them." So this is a way that
Pare was able to tell diverse trans stories using
this innovative medium.

And at the same time, they
were also teaching VR skills to young people.

And then this next
example, this is actually an HCI researcher in Brazil
named Guilherme Pereira.

And he was using
participatory design methods over a period of
more than six months

with a group of trans and
queer people in Brazil. And they ended up creating this
app called LGB Trust, which

is trying to increase safety
in physical spaces for trans and queer people in Brazil.

And so in this human-centered
design process, Pereira was learning
with participants

that safety was
a primary concern and that they wanted the app
to focus on safety primarily.

He said, "This is
very deeply related to all these concerns
about violence in Brazil.

So it was natural to talk about
and to think about safety, how to create a safe place,
to share about what

places you should be careful,
where you should not go. But it was not given by
me, it was not my choice

at the beginning. It was just the natural
development of the project." And so he went into this
process not knowing what

the app was going to focus on. But in the workshops,
along with participants,

they decided that they
really would be focusing on safety for this app.

But there is an
important tension here. So despite this empowering
and potentially liberatory

possibilities of
trans technology, many of these technologies
were not actually deployed or were short-lived.

So this was especially
true for those that used these more exemplary
human-centered design processes.

And a lot of times this happens
most often in academic spaces.

So I'm sure a lot of you
are familiar with this. We have a lot of incentive in
academia to create technologies,

to design them,
but not necessarily to deploy and maintain them. And this is exactly
what happened in the case of LGB Trust.

So Perera was describing to me
the barriers to deploying it, and he said that he
deployed the app,

but it was like a
prototype deployment. "I had most of these
functionalities working so people could ask for help,
people could post things,

it would appear in the
map, and people could ask for any other kind of support. I think that in the end, and
this is something that really

frustrated me at the time, for
you to be able to deploy an app, you need a lot of money, and
you need a lot of people working

with you." So this was a safety
app, so it really needed to work really
well without any issues,

if it was actually going
to keep people safe. And so it was quite
disappointing for the researcher

and also for the people who
were involved in the study, that the app was
not fully deployed.

And as a recap of my
primary arguments here, creating trans technology can
be powerful and empowering

because tech creators
have this agency to create the tools that
they and their communities

need to navigate the world. But then when trans
communities are not involved in the
design process, this

can lead to this overly
individualistic design that speaks primarily to more
privileged trans people's needs.

And so I argue, trans tech
creation can be most impactful and best address trans needs
if we have diverse community

members who are meaningfully
involved in the design process. So what should we do about it?

How can we address some
of these inequalities that occur when design is more
overtly individualistic?

So this is how
I've been thinking about moving towards
more community-based tech

deployment and maintenance,
rather than just design. So this dark gray
circle here, this

is people who really understand
community needs and values, and that is basically diverse
trans communities in this case.

And then the next
circle is people who really have the skills,
resources and interests

to design technology. And that would be the
creators of trans technology that I spoke with in this study.

And there is overlap between
that and the diverse trans communities. But then there's
this third circle

here at the bottom,
which is people who have the skills
and the resources and the interest to deploy
and maintain technology.

And that is the one
that doesn't as often come into these trans
tech design processes.

And as far as I know,
there are actually very, very few
trans technologies that are at the
center of this circle.

And that leaves
quite a few gaps. And so this is a small excerpt
from a long list of categories

of trans challenges that my
research team and I came up with in participatory
research with communities.

And so the first column here
is types of trans technologies that currently address
this challenge.

So if we look at
the second row here, there's a lot of challenges
around access to documents,

things like passports
and driver's licenses and being able to change one's
name and gender marker on those.

But as far as I
know, there are not any trans technologies that are
currently working in this space.

And so the second
column here is ways that trans technologies
can help address

this challenge to some extent. So we could think
about digital systems to help people change
their names and gender

markers on these
identification documents, or even just resources
for how to do that.

And then the third
column here is aspects that are not possible to
fully address with technology,

so more systemic issues. So there's things like
transphobia and racism. And we're never going to
be able to actually solve

any of these systemic
problems with a technology. And so I tend to
talk about this more

as helping to address challenges
rather than offering solutions to these challenges because
there are always parts of it

that we can't actually do here. I think that also applies
to things like policies and some of these really harmful
legislation that is coming out.

And so there's a
mismatch here, and that is that people are
mostly designing

based on their own needs. So they're not starting
from this place of examining what the community needs are.

And so that's the
reason why we don't have any document-related
trans technologies.

But we do have, for instance,
a trans banking app, which is something
that nobody asked for.

[LAUGHTER] So a little pause before
I get to the conclusion.

So just pause,
take a deep breath. Try not to think about
the state of the world.

So as I start to wrap up
here, I want to leave you with this primary takeaway.

So trends technologies
really show how technology can
help us imagine new possibilities for trans
people and communities.

And then at the same
time, trans experiences can help us imagine new
possibilities for technology.

So in this first
category, I told you about this example of
trans family network.

And this is a way that
trans technologies help people in unique ways that
they may not have considered.

So initially, people were
using a spreadsheet for this, but now we have a
technology that can

do this in a much better way. Another example of
this is something

called Mod Club, which
is a online community and resource-sharing,
photo-sharing community

for mostly people on the
transmasculine spectrum.

And then at the
same time, there are ways that trans experiences help
us imagine new possibilities

for technology. So this is a really
cool example. This is also coming from
some HCI researchers,

and this is a series
of facial prosthetics that enable you to have multiple
identities using Apple Face ID.

So if you think about
unlocking your iPhone, you do that using your face.

And since each of us
only has one face, we can only have one
identity on our iPhone.

But you can imagine in things
like gender transition, that you might need to
have multiple identities

at the same time. And a way to do that is to
have these facial prosthetics.

So this was a participatory
design project where they worked
with community members

to create some of
these technologies, test them out, things like that. And they started to
realize that it wasn't

just useful for trans
experiences on iPhone, it was also really useful
for assisting surveillance

in public spaces. So if you think
about a lot of cities have cameras surveilling you in
public spaces, a lot of people

would like to obfuscate that. And these facial
prosthetics ended up being a way to do that as well.

So it came out of the
context of thinking about trans experiences,
but it went far beyond that.

And then this is one of
my favorite examples. This is Chelsea Manning. She's a famous
whistleblower, and she

was in prison for a
number of years for that. And when she was in prison,
she was transitioning,

and nobody knew what she looked
like as a woman, basically. And there was a
magazine that wanted

to do a feature on Chelsea. They wanted to have a
photographer to take pictures of her, but that was
not allowed in the prison.

And so the magazine
reached out to an artist named Heather Dewey-Hagborg,
who is a artist that

does DNA phenotyping work. And I was able to
talk with Heather as one of the interviewees
in this study.

And she told me about
this collaborative process with Chelsea, where
Chelsea sent Heather

basically hair
clippings, cheek swabs, different things like this so
that she could use her DNA.

And Heather then created all
of these different potential versions of what
Chelsea might look like.

And they called this
project probably Chelsea. And so they were able,
in the computer code,

to get rid of all of the
potential options that would be male
versions of Chelsea,

and only have it so
that it was either female or
gender-neutral versions. And so this is what it
ended up looking like.

This is Chelsea after she got
out of prison, coming face to face with this art exhibit.

So I think this is a really cool
example of very innovative, very unique ways that we
can use technology

that comes from thinking
about trans experiences, but goes very far beyond that.

And so I want to end
on an optimistic note. And I want to read this
short excerpt from the book

that I think demonstrates
my optimism, especially in the face of these
very difficult times.

"So as we continue
to search for ways to emerge from the toxic climate
that trans people are currently

forced to inhabit,
we can set our sights on trans technologies
on the horizon and start to build those
technologies that help

us escape transphobic worlds. I personally tend toward a
more optimistic, utopian view.

I have immense hope for
those 16-year-olds sitting in their bedrooms and
their parents' houses,

or in libraries, or in
youth drop-in centers, hacking at their keyboards
to create browser extensions.

Those vast armies of
trans game creators channeling their rage and
creativity into trans game jams,

and all those people
building new technologies to help address the challenges
their community faces.

Each of these
creators are ripples extending out from
earlier trans technologies that have inspired them.

And at the same time, they're
also new objects breaking the surface, and they will
inspire waves of future trans

technologies spreading out
across the water toward the horizon."
Thank you. [APPLAUSE]
